case_vignette: A 3-month-old boy presents for routine health maintenance. The patient has coarse facial features and stiff joint movements with restricted passive and active range of motion. He also has problems following objects with his eyes and seems not to focus on anything. On physical examination, the corneas are clouded, and the patient fails to meet any 3-month developmental milestones. Genetic testing and histopathology are performed and reveal failure of a cellular structure to phosphorylate mannose residues on glycoproteins. An electron microscopy image of one of this patient’s cells is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby has rough-looking facial features, seems to struggle with stiff joints and moving them, and doesn't seem to track objects or focus his gaze on anything.
Can you tell me your baby's age and sex?
He is a 3-month-old boy.
Has your baby had any previous medical conditions or surgeries?
No, he hasn't had any previous medical conditions or surgeries.
Has your baby been taking any medications or supplements?
No, he hasn't been taking any medications or supplements.
Has your baby's family history included any genetic disorders or medical conditions?
I'm sorry, but I don't have any information about the family history to share.

Based on the symptoms you've described, it's possible that your baby may have a genetic disorder called Down syndrome. Down syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that can cause physical and intellectual challenges. It's characterized by a range of physical features, including a flat face, small ears, and short, stubby fingers. It can also cause difficulty with joint mobility and difficulty tracking objects or focusing the gaze.

Final Diagnosis: Down syndrome.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby has rough facial features, seems to have trouble moving his joints smoothly, and isn't able to follow objects with his eyes or focus on things well.
What is your baby's age?
My baby is 3 months old.
Has your baby been born prematurely?
The scenario doesn't specify whether my baby was born prematurely.
Has your baby been diagnosed with any medical conditions before?
No, he hasn't been diagnosed with any medical conditions before this.
Has your baby been exposed to any environmental toxins or chemicals?
The scenario doesn't mention any exposure to environmental toxins or chemicals.

The scenario doesn't provide information about my baby's vaccination status.
Has your baby been screened for any genetic disorders?
Yes, my baby has undergone genetic testing.
What was the result of the genetic testing?
The genetic testing showed a problem with a certain process in my baby's cells involving sugars on proteins.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation (CDG)
